newsitem.title: ETHIOPIA: Ethiopia urges farmers to produce quality coffee.
newsitem.headline: Ethiopia urges farmers to produce quality coffee.

text.p: A top Ethiopian coffee official on Wednesday appealed to farmers to produce quality coffee which could compete on the market with the world's best.
Abayneh Alemu, deputy general manager of the Coffee and Tea Authority, told a coffee performance evaluation workshop emphasis should be on improved coffee production and quality.
"Research in the past years has done very little to address quality improvement in coffee production, harvesting and marketing," said Abayneh, demanding action in that direction.
Ethiopian authorities have forecast coffee exports in 1996/97 crop year (October/September) at 108,000 tonnes -- the biggest export volume in the country's trade history.
Ethiopia exported 102,000 tonnes of coffee in 1995/96 which earned it $279.5 million -- lower than the $300.9 million it received for exporting 78,420 tonnes of coffee in 1994/95.
Government Coffee authorities and private exporters blamed poor global prices for the decline in Ethiopia export earnings.
Ethiopia is Africa's third largest producer of coffee after Uganda and Ivory Coast. Coffee is its main export commodity and accounts for about 60 percent of its foreign exchange revenue.
Abayneh said coffee was grown in almost all parts of Ethiopia with the bulk of the produce "in appreciable quantity" coming from three major catagories -
-- forest coffee which is typical to the regions of western Ethiopia where self-sown wild coffee trees grow naturally.
-- garden coffee grown at low densities around homes by domestication of forest coffee.
-- plantation coffee where high yield varities are grown following recommended cultural practices.

Ethiopia's exportable coffee is marketed at daily auctions. Exporters bid for specific lots based on samples displayed at the auction centre. The bulk of Ethiopian coffee is sold on description basis. A smaller segment is sold on sample and cup quality, according to trade officials.
Ethiopia's exports comprise of washed coffees such as Yirgascheffe, Sidamo, Limu and Babaka, unwashed coffee such as Jimma, Lekemt, Sidamo, Harar and special blends, Abayneh said.
